content: seattle salmon by karen mortensen materials 1 skein blue sky organic cotton 150 yds or cascade 220 paints 220 yards size g 4 0 mm crochet hook or size needed to get gauge removable stitch marker 1 pair plastic safety eyes or black yarn for embroidering eyes cotton wool or polyester stuffing gauge 4 single_crochet/inch although gauge is not crucial crochet tightly enough to keep the stuffing from showing through abbreviations chain chain half_double_crochet half-double_crochet single_crochet single_crochet decrease single_crochet two together decrease insert hook in next stitch and pull up a loop 2 loops on hook then insert hook in the following stitch and pull up a loop 3 loops on hook yarn over and pull through all three loops on hook st stitch 2sc place two single crochets in the same stitch notes -do not join your rounds instead work in a spiral move your stitch marker to the loop on the hook at the end of each round to signify the beginning of a new one -on the patterned section each time you half_double_crochet into the front loop of a stitch on the previous round you are skipping the stitch that corresponds to it right above it on your current round the front loop should look like a little bar in the row below every other stitch you are alternating one stitch from your current round and one stitch from the row below it -if you are making a toy for a baby or small child embroidering eyes on is the safest method to create them -stuff your fish very full of stuffing because it can compress over time fill the body as full as possibly after completing the patterned section and then add more stuffing before closing the tail instructions chain 2 in the back loop of 2nd chain from hook single_crochet 6 round 1 place a stitch marker on the loop on your hook to mark the beginning of the round starting at first single_crochet single_crochet in each st around 6 sts round 2 2sc in next st single_crochet 2sc in each of next two sts
